docs.lead_paragraph: Jim Wilson, who drives his pickup truck around the country to campaign for Mitt Romney, has become a charming counterpoint to a sometimes awkward candidate.

headline.seo: A Zealous Romney Fan Becomes a Valuable Campaign Asset
headline.main: On the Road for Romney, 40,000 Miles and Counting
headline.print_headline: On the Road For Romney, 40,000 Miles And Counting

docs.abstract: Jim Wilson, a 69-year-old former life insurance salesman, has devoted himself to following presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney around the country, driving a pickup truck festooned with giant Romney for President posters; Wilson has become unexpectedly valuable to the campaign, helping with events and offering a charming counterpoint to a sometimes awkward Romney.
docs.snippet: Jim Wilson, who drives his pickup truck around the country to campaign for Mitt Romney, has become a charming counterpoint to a sometimes awkward candidate.

docs.lead_paragraph: John J. Myers, the archbishop of Newark, writes about religious freedom under the Obama’s administration’s final health rules.

headline.main: Religious Freedom: An American Bishop’s View
headline.print_headline: Religious Freedom: An American Bishop’s View

docs.abstract: Letter from John J Myers, the archbishop of Newark, responds to May 22 news article on lawsuit by forty-three Catholic groups challenging the Obama administration’s rule that employees receive health insurance coverage for contraception.
docs.snippet: John J. Myers, the archbishop of Newark, writes about religious freedom under the Obama’s administration’s final health rules.

docs.abstract: After Dominick Brocato’s account of being fired and unemployed was published here earlier this week, readers asked for an update. Here it is.
docs.snippet: After Dominick Brocato’s account of being fired and unemployed was published here earlier this week, readers asked for an update. Here it is.

byline.original: By DOMINICK BROCATO and DW GIBSON

docs.abstract: Republicans are fighting against automatic defense cuts.
docs.snippet: Republicans are fighting against automatic defense cuts.

headline.main: The Fork in the Road for Health Care

docs.abstract: Without major changes in health care costs, the day of rationing of care draws near, even if elected officials dare not mention it, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Without major changes in health care costs, the day of rationing of care draws near, even if elected officials dare not mention it, an economist writes.

docs.snippet: Corrections appearing in print on May 25, 2012.

docs.lead_paragraph: A measure to prevent drug shortages and to accelerate federal review of new and generic medications won broad support, with a similar bill on a fast track to approval in the House.

headline.seo: Senate Backs Bill to Speed Drugs and Avert Shortages
headline.main: Senate Backs Bipartisan Bill to Speed Drugs and Avert Shortages
headline.print_headline: Senate Backs Bipartisan Bill to Speed Drugs and Avert Shortages

docs.abstract: Senate passes a major bipartisan bill to prevent drug shortages and to speed federal approval of lifesaving medicines, including lower-cost generic versions of biotechnology products; similar bill, strongly supported by Pres Obama, consumer groups and pharmaceutical companies, is on a fast track to approval in the House.
docs.snippet: A measure to prevent drug shortages and to accelerate federal review of new and generic medications won broad support, with a similar bill on a fast track to approval in the House.

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a study on the coverage available from health insurance policies gave an outdated name for a research center where the study's lead author, Jon R. Gabel, works. He is a health researcher at NORC at the University of Chicago; it is no longer known as the National Opinion Research Center.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than three decades after private equity burst onto the scene in the merger mania of the 1980s, the industry remains as mysterious and controversial as ever.

headline.main: Political Ads Don’t Tell Full Story on Private Equity
headline.print_headline: Political Ads Don’t Tell Full Story on Private Equity

docs.abstract: Relationship between the private equity industry and job creation is far more nuanced than portraits painted in advertisements for the Romney and Obama campaigns.
docs.snippet: More than three decades after private equity burst onto the scene in the merger mania of the 1980s, the industry remains as mysterious and controversial as ever.

docs.lead_paragraph: Insurers, hospitals and doctors say they are forming partnerships and creating programs to find ways to slow the growth in the nation’s $2.7 trillion health care bill.

headline.seo: Hospitals and Insurers Join to Cut Health Care Costs
headline.main: For Hospitals and Insurers, New Fervor to Cut Costs
headline.print_headline: New Fervor for Cutting Costs Among Hospitals and Insurers

docs.abstract: Hospitals, doctors and health insurers, after years of self-acknowledged profligacy, undertake strong effort to bring medical costs under control; goal is to slash the rate of growth in the nation's $2.7 trillion health care bill by roughly half to keep it more in line with overall inflation; private insurers, employers and government officials are providing urgency to these efforts.
docs.snippet: Insurers, hospitals and doctors say they are forming partnerships and creating programs to find ways to slow the growth in the nation’s $2.7 trillion health care bill.
